Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Investigating the Causal Propositions of the Affect Heuristic During an Ongoing Pandemic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: The unprecedented pandemic wrought by the coronavirus has infected many people around the world, triggering anxiety and panic and disrupting all facets of life. In addition to the growing numbers of cases and deaths, the social, economic, and political impacts are vast. Lacking a vaccine or effective therapeutic cure, the front line of defense against the spread of this disease depends on human behavior, following guidelines about social distancing, sanitation, and other recommended measures. There is great uncertainty about the future trajectory of the disease and its impacts. Against the backdrop of this catastrophic threat this research forecasts public perceptions of risks, including hopes and fears, using a new theoretical model based on what is known as “the affect heuristic.” The researchers build and test this model in two ways that increase understanding of how positive and negative emotions, influenced by daily news reports, interact to guide behavior. Understanding the changing reactions to news information not only advances understanding of risk perception, but enables the creation of effective risk communication messages. The research provides insight into the behaviors that will determine the course of the disease and can help to mitigate its harmful social and economic impacts.<br/><br/>Studies have consistently found an inverse relationship between judgments of benefits and risks associated with a wide array of hazards. This relationship occurs because perceptions of risk and benefit are derived in opposite ways from an affective sense of the importance of the risk. This process became known as the affect heuristic. The causal dynamics that underlie the relationship between affect and perceived risks and benefits remain poorly understood. This project does three things: (1a) constructs a system dynamics simulation model that explicitly incorporates the informational feedback loops that allow affect to play this moderating role and (1b) simulates the trajectories of affect and perceived risk and benefits as the coronavirus pandemic unfolds, (2) constructs a hybrid agent-based model that incorporates findings from the systems model but allows for heterogeneity (e.g., different levels of medical vulnerability) among agents, and (3) conducts a longitudinal national panel to survey the public’s response to the pandemic over a 6 month period. These data together with data from an independent panel are be used to estimate and validate both models. This project has broad impacts because understanding how we manage our perceptions of risk and benefits is critical to the decisions we make and our behaviors. The project helps to explain this entanglement and predict public reaction to the current pandemic and, potentially, to other crises.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has two primary objectives: To track public response to the COVID-19 pandemic and to examine and model the causal mechanisms the underlie the affect heuristic and investigate how this heuristic contributes to the attenuation and amplification of perceived risk, primarily in the context of COVID-19.

Public reaction to the COVID-19 pandemic was tracked by following the same panel of respondents across three nationwide online surveys over the period from April 2020 to October 2021. The surveys took approximately 15 minutes to complete. The surveys were designed to measure Americans? perceptions of information related to the COVID-19 pandemic. Measures of perceived risk and benefits were collected across a wide assortment of issues pertaining to public health, national economy, jobs, retirement, public transportation and vaccination. Of particular interest was using various measures of perceived risks and benefits to better understand the affect heuristic?the observed phenomenon that risk and benefit tend to be perceived as inversely related?in an evolving global crisis.

Data for Survey 1 were collected in April 2020 from 2,012 American participants. Classification questions were asked about age, gender, education, party affiliation, political conservatism, health status, job status and media use. Inquiries were also made about perceptions of risk to public health and the economy posed by the ongoing pandemic. Perceptions of possible benefits to public health and the economy emerging from the pandemic were also investigated. Data for Survey 2 were collected in June 2020 from 1,112 participants who had completed Survey 1. In addition to the questions asked in the previous survey, respondents were asked to generate their thoughts about both the state of public health and the economy due to the pandemic. They then rated these thoughts on two scales reflecting positive and negative feelings. Data for Survey 3 were collected in October 2021 from 682 respondents who completed the previous two surveys. In addition to the questions posed in the previous two surveys, respondents were asked about their perceptions of vaccination risks and benefits as well as their vaccination status.

Results to date confirm the inverse relationship between perceptions of risk and benefit reported in previous investigations of the affect heuristic. These findings are now generalized to a widespread ongoing hazard, the pandemic. Response to the pandemic appears to be moderated by political party affiliation. For example, there were differences between Democrats and Republicans in terms of their perceptions of how health and economic conditions changed for the better throughout the pandemic. Democrats and Republicans appear to have experienced the pandemic differently. Regarding changing health conditions in the country, Democrats had a uniformly higher level of positivity than Republicans. Conversely, Democrats began by having more positive attitudes about the economy than Republicans but ended up having considerably less positive attitudes than Republicans.

In terms of attitudes towards vaccination. a logistic regression model was estimated using data from Survey 3. The model computed the probability of being vaccinated (or planning to get vaccinated) based on levels of perceived risk and benefits. This was done both for Democrats and Republicans. For both parties, when perceived benefits are high the chances of being or getting vaccinated are very high regardless of the level of perceived risk. Conversely, low levels of perceived risk do not necessarily result in high probabilities of being vaccinated. Likewise for all combinations of perceived risks and benefits Democrats have a higher chance of being vaccinated. Perceptions of benefits appear to be more important than perceptions of risk in predicting reported willingness to get vaccinated.

A prototype system dynamics simulation model has also been proposed to examine the mechanisms responsible for the inverse relationship observed between perceived risk and benefits. Examination of the model is underway at this point. Findings could provide an explanation of how individuals and communities recover from or possibly forget their experience of risky events and behaviors. Messaging during a crisis either stressing the risks and or emphasizing benefits of different courses of action likely influences perceptions of the same. This suggests it is critically important to strike a thoughtful balance between risk and benefit information when communicating with the public about hazardous events, technologies or behaviors.
